> opponent. Given this stipulation what is a perfect player?  A perfect
> p=
layer must assume that the opponent is strong, and therefore must play
> de=
fensively whilst trying to keep winning lines open as a secondary goal
> on=
ly - and only making a winning move if the opportunity arises.

It's possib=
le there is no perfect player given no knowledge of the
opponent.  I haven'=
t done enough analysis of tic-tac-toe to know if
it's simple enough that yo=
u can have an absolute perfect strategy, but
in our experience there is not=
 one.  There can be moves that are
sub-optimal against a good opponent but =
optimal against a weak
opponent, and vice versa.

Let's say move A will res=
ult in a loss 100% of the time against a
strong opponent but, against a wea=
k opponent, results in a win 70%,
loss 10%, and tie 20%.  Move B results in=
 a tie 100% of the time
against any opponent.  Let's assume wins are worth =
+1, ties 0, losses
-1.

What's the best move in that case?  What would a "p=
erfect" player do? 
What will the fittest player do?  It depends on the opp=
onents it is
facing.  You argue it should assume a strong opponent and move=

accordingly.  But, in this case, if a player has a 50-50 chance of
facing =
a strong or weak opponent, move B is the better choice.

- Philip
